talk.start.para: I have referred to the scholarships provided by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, to answer criticism advanced by Senator Dittmer. I have indicated what is being done in the various universities across the face of Australia, to establish the fact that the commission has provided, in the year under review, approximately 30,000 for the purpose of permitting special research studies to be undertaken. I have tried to emphasize that throughout the world there has been a lessening of the striving for nuclear power, the reason being, as the Minister has indicated, greater development of conventional methods of producing power a world surplus of oil, which is one of the sources of power, and increased pro duction of coal. I have taken Australia as an example, and I have shown that in the early post-war years we were tragically short of coal for industry, although we had great coal resources, and that it was necessary to ration power, with the result that there were blackouts.

speech.para: I wish to refer to the basic thought behind the Minister's speech. Having founded a uranium industry in this country, and in view of the tremendous advantages that that could have for us, we should encourage the industry to develop, despite the fact that there has been a world tendency to slow down the development of nuclear power. The Department of National Development is continuing to assist in the search for uranium, lt is wrong to imagine that Australia has discovered all the uranium deposits that it needs. During 1958-59, only five new discoveries of radio-active minerals were reported by agencies of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, and none of those discoveries was of any significance. In the year under review, none of the discoveries of radioactive minerals was significant in the sense that it gave hope that it would lead to the winning of large quantities of uranium ore.

The position at Rum Jungle should be a matter of concern for all of us. As we know, at Rum Jungle there are White's deposits, Dyson's deposits, and the deposits at Mount Burton. A huge treatment plant has been erected there. In common with many other honorable senators, I have had the privilege of visiting Rum Jungle. Con sequent on the establishment of the treatment plant, the amenities that are usually associated with the employment of a considerable number of people have been provided. For instance, there is a swimming pool, and there are home units for the working community, sporting fields, and so on. While it is true that the capital cost has been amortized and charged against the yield, the plain fact is that all the uranium has been mined and is now stored for treatment. By 1962, all the ore that is now at grass will have been used. Unless we find more uranium there, the installations at Rum Jungle either will have to remain there to rot or be dismantled and taken elsewhere. In either event, the industry will come to an end.

I understand the ore has been discovered at Adelaide River, which is within a reason able distance of Rum Jungle, and that some of the ore has been taken to Rum Jungle for treatment. It can be seen, therefore, that there is an urgent need to continue the search for uranium in the Rum Jungle area, so that the installations can be used effectively in the future and so that the capital outlay will not go for nothing. The search for uranium in the Northern Terri tory is proceeding at a reasonable pace. If honorable senators pick up the report of the Atomic Energy Commission they will see in it an account of what is being done in the Territory. I conclude my comments about the search for uranium there by say ng that there is an urgent need to find more uranium.

In Queensland, the position in regard to uranium is a much happier one. We all know the story of the development of Mount Isa. An area of approximately 3,500 square miles is being subjected to a low-level radiometric survey. Most of us are aware of the story of Mary Kathleen. Anderson's lode has been examined and reported on, and it is estimated that the deposits there amount to approximately 1,000,000 tons of ore. In South Australia, there is the Radium Hill field. In Western Australia, the commission is pushing on with aero magnetic surveys in the hope that discoveries will be made. Although there has been a reduction in the striving for nuclear developments throughout the world, if we can locate new uranium deposits in this country, Australia will be in the happy position of being able to capitalize on the world demand for uranium which may come in the future. As I said earlier in my remarks, we need to find not substitute industries but support industries for our wool industry. A uranium export industry would be of considerable help to us economically.

Having said that, Mr. Deputy President, I think I have stated in one sentence why is necessary for us to have the Lucas Heights research establishment. I do not presume to understand the minutest fraction of nuclear science, but I think that the seventh annual report of the Atomic Energy Commission, of which we have all been given copies and which is the basis of this debate, is a document that all of us should read. To do so should encourage us to seek further information. The report makes one realize the great importance that this industry could have for the future of Australia. I listened with considerable interest to the speech made by Senator Branson, in the course of which he referred to Hifar, a reactor for the testing of materials.

But it has another roleth e production of radio isotopes. The honorable senator is to be congratulated on his research which enabled us to appreciate the significance of isotopes in the future development of Australia. He was able to tell us how iso topes could be used in industrial develop ment and in the medical field. He showed us how medical science has been able to gain advantage from isotopes in the search for ways to ameliorate cancer, if not cure it. We should also be conscious of the advantage that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization has obtained from isotopes. AU this progress has sprung from the original major decision to establish the Atomic Energy Commission. It is important to realize that with our small population of 10,000,000 people our economy is limited; we cannot be compared with Europe in that respect. But despite those limitations we have been able to create the Atomic Energy Commis sion and to build one reactor at Lucas Heights for special study. There we are able to train our young scientists in nuclear science. We can second them to other parts of the world for further studies, and when they return they will form a hard core of scientists so that when we can develop the next stage in the use of nuclear power we shall be able to get the utmost benefit from it.

I read in the press recently that a member of the House of Representatives referred to the need for establishing an atomic reactor in Australia as a matter of urgency. The press heading read " Overwhelming Case for Start of Atomic Reactor". It has been pointed out that some of our greatest industrial undertakings are separated from the normal grid systems for the supply of power. They include the Mount Isa Mines, the great enterprise at Broken Hill and others in South Australia, for example. The suggestion was that because of the isolation of our great industrial undertakings, we should be able to build special reactors and establish them in industrial areas so that they might provide power for those industries. However, when one listens to the details of the cost of building atomic reactors, such as those given by the Minister for National Development (Senator Spooner) in this chamber recently, one realizes that we are not quite ready for such a development in Australia yet. The Minister said it was anticipated that under the best conditions overseas, the cost of establishing a reactor would be about 30,000,000. Clearly it would be futile for us to establish power reactors at a capital cost of that magnitude and place them in areas where only a fraction of the power produced would be used. I agree with the Minister that the logical thing to do would be to establish these reactors, when the time comes, in strategic areas where they could be the basis of, and be integrated into, the power grids of the big industrial States.

I have nothing more to contribute to this debate beyond saying that the report of the Atomic Energy Commission is a most convincing document which will stimulate us all to strive towards a greater know ledge of this problem. We should take pride in the fact that this nation of 10,000,000 people has been able to embark on the work of this commission as it has done. We should take satisfaction in the fact that we have uranium in Australia. We should not relax our search for further fields because uranium is a source of revenue which will mean a happier, more progressive and prosperous life for our people. Above all, we should hope that nuclear power and atomic power will be used exclusively for peaceful purposes. It is significant that the policy of this Government is to allow the export of uranium only for peaceful purposes. I am certain that if we make this great source of power work for peace Australia and the world generally will thus secure the greatest bene fit from the discovery of uranium which so dramatically launched Australia in the rated from the normal grid systems for field of nuclear science.

talk.start.para: . - Like most other honorable senators, 1 feel there is not very much I know about the subject under discussion. It is a matter for experts. All we can do as laymen is to express our views on the way the world is going in the application of nuclear science. I am happy about the note of restraint that has been evident in this debate. The report of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission reveals that a number of committees have been appointed. That indicates to me that it will be a long time before we get anywhere or do anything of real value in connexion with this matter. My experience of expert committees is that the more you have of them and the more experts there are on the committees, the safer it is and the longer it takes to reach a decision.

speech.para: However, my purpose in rising is to refer to the speech delivered this week on this subject by the Minister for National Development (Senator Spooner). The Minister said, for example -

quote.para: I think the correct way to approach this matter is to make two points at the beginning. The first is the tremendous importance to Australia of power in its various manifestations. One is rather apt to deal with this subject of power in general terms, but the provision of power has such ramifications that I thought I might traverse some of them. My second point is to emphasize the importance of providing power to the community at an economic rate. Because of the vast sums of money involved, the development of trends in power and the way in which the various types of power are brought into operation will depend almost entirely in my opinion, on the competitive economics of the three different types of power.

speech.para: I believe that economics should not be the guiding rule in this matter. If economics are going to determine what fuel should be used, that would be wrong because it might not be in the best interests of Australia. For instance, we have expended millions of pounds on the Snowy Mountains hydroelectric project. We have spent similar amounts of money on the coal industry. We have great reserves of coal and great towns on the coal-fields. All these matters must be considered. I think I speak for the Australian Labour Party when I say that the world is already going too fast. I do not mind if I do not see nuclear energy in my lifetime, because there are certain dangers associated with it. The world crashed into a nuclear energy campaign. Australia is only a small country and there is not much that we can do in this field. We must tag along in the rear, and to do so would be a good investment. Why should we engage in expensive experimentation in nuclear energy when the powerful nations are doing it for us? Let us tag along. If we do that we shall have nothing to be ashamed of. Our experts may learn what is going on about us, but we have not the capital to engage even in such a programme as that undertaken by Britain, which finds too expensive the work being done by the United States and the Soviet Union.

Another point is that we have not yet extracted everything that is to be extracted by the present means of production. We have not completely entered the age of automation, although we are moving into it. Big business interests here are alive to the situation and they advise restraint. I remember when Professor Harry Messel went around trying to encourage a crash campaign on nuclear energy. He established committees but he found great difficulty in raising much money. He addressed trade unions and employers' organizations. He is a master salesman but they were very slow to put in their money. I do not know how much he raised for his university organization, but I was pleased to note that the industrialists did not rush headlong into a campaign for the introduction of nuclear methods to industry. I do not think that that is necessary in this country at this stage, although some day it may be necessary. Harry Messel, of course, was doing his job.

I was pleased at the note of restraint that permeated Senator Spooner's speech. I want to speak about the coal industry, because Senator Spooner made some references to it that need elaboration. He was the first person on the Government side to indicate that while coal could be produced economically there was no danger of its being supplanted by nuclear energy. I think he went almost so far as to say that, and I am with him to that extent. He spoke about the future of coal and its price. He said that although coal cost 4 10s. a ton in 1952, it might be down to 30s. a ton by 1970. I do not think that he meant to imply that because of new production techniques the price of coal would fall so low. He was referring specifically to power-house coal. Although it may be possible to obtain cheap coal for power, coal will not necessarily be cheap to other industries, such as shipping or railways. It will be cheap for power-house purposes because of the action of the Cahill Labour Government of New South Wales. 1 think Senator Spooner should have mentioned that fact. After all, Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett-A.N.A. get plugs, but I do not hear from the other side many plugs for a Labour government. The price of some coal in New South Wales will fall to 30s. a ton because of the work of the Cahill Labour Government and the State Electricity Commission. The two men who deserve the credit are the late Premier, Mr. J. J. Cahill, and the late Mr. Conde, who was chairman of the State Electricity Commission. Those two men were responsible for the revolution in coal prices. Instead of carrying coal hundreds of miles from mines to power-houses, they did the obvious thing, but something that the coal-owners do not attempt to do. Mr. Cahill and Mr. Conde took the powerhouses to the coal. Only yesterday we read of the establishment of three new mines, from which the coal will go straight into the power-house at Vales Point on Lake Macquarie. Freight costs have been a big item in coal distribution costs in Australia. It was the New South Wales Government which did this great work.

talk.start.para: Did the Joint Coal Board have something to do with it?

In an overall advisory sense, yes, but basically it was the work of the mining group operated by the New South Wales Government, which naturally was more flexible than the private coal-owners. The State Government, own ing leases, was able to say, " We shall start a mine there ". I do not suggest that a wonderful improvement has not been made in underground production by coal owners, but the great drawback to coal as a fuel has been its cost. For instance, the Victorian market was lost to the South Maitland coal-field, not because of the cost of getting coal out of the ground, but be cause it cost 5 10s. a ton to take it to the market. The same applied to the South Australian market. That was why New South Wales lost its interstate coal markets.

speech.para: Generally speaking, of course, means of production are being improved and mechanization is, overall, reducing the cost. But there are certain dangers. Senator Spooner referred to competition between the various fuels. That is a rather dangerous idea. I do not think that there should be any competition in fuel or in power. I think it is just as illogical to have competition amongst power sellers as it would be to have competition amongst water sellers. My view is that production of power should proceed in accordance with a plan. I hope to goodness that the Minister does not envisage the coal industry, the Snowy Mountains Authority, and even the oi) companies, having to fight it out with the producers of nuclear energy to see who can produce the cheapest power. That would be a bad day for humanity everywhere. It would bring us to the end quicker than would the atomic bomb, in my view. What we need is some type of board or institution that will co-ordinate all power-producing agencies. It might be decided that coal should be used to produce 65 per cent, of our power and that the balance, should be hydro-electric power, or power produced by using oil fuel. Some planned approach should be made to power production, because the manufacturing industries want to know where they are going in relation to power. They want to know that, just as much as they want to know where they stand in relation to future finance. They want to be told what power they will be getting over the next twenty years. I repeat that it will be very wrong indeed to allow this matter to be decided on the basis of economic competition because Australia certainly could not hope to gain under such a system.

Another interesting point was that Senator Spooner warned us that it should not be taken for granted that the Government itself would be interested in the control or development of industries connected with the development of atomic energy. I was sorry to hear that; I earnestly hope that no government in any part of the world will allow control of this great force to get into the hands of private enterprise. Senator Spooner said that he would not like it to be thought that the Government was entering this field.

talk.start.para: - He did not suggest what you are inferring from his remarks.

I certainly hope that that is so. After all, we cannot always have things just as we would like them in the development of society. I am firmly convinced that it would be extremely unsafe to allow the control of the development of this highly scientific process to get into the hands of private enterprise, and I do not think that will be allowed to happen In any case, I do not think it could be financed without aid from the national purse, so that on that ground alone private enterprise will not be able to enjoy a free hand in connexion with atomic energy.

speech.para: I have heard it said here that we should be pushing on with the development of nuclear energy, and it seems strange to me that we should hear this advocacy at a time when statesmen all over the world are rushing about endeavouring to arrange summit conferences to guard against the undesirable features which can result from the development of this new science which has arisen since the splitting of the atom. If we could ensure that the development of all these great inventions be directed to the good of mankind, we should certainly support them to the full; but we must always bear in mind the thought that the danger arising from their development may be too great to warrant proceeding with the work. The world is approaching the development of nuclear energy with great caution; and well it might, because each new development brings its own problems with it. I feel, too, that it could be that the authorities know more about this new development than they would like us to know and that therefore there is restraint the world over in connexion with it. If that is so, then it is possible that we shall not hear a great deal more about it until developments have reached a stage at which this science will be put only to uses calculated to serve the best interests of humanity. I therefore suggest that this or any other government would be well advised to move slowly along with the rest of the world, keeping in touch with developments and always bearing in mind that new problems will arise as we progress along the atomic road.

During the recent development of our industrial system there has been a to forget the social implications involved. For instance, Senator Spooner referred to the sale of coal at 30s. a ton. That could by anybody be taken to mean that coal would be produced mechanically and that eventually we should see the total elimination of men from the mines. It could mean that there will be gasification, and so on. So, I submit that with each phase of development we should engage in a campaign of research into ways of rehabilitating the various sections of the community which may be affected by the new developments. I do not think anyone wants to stop progress. The workers certainly do not want to stop it, but the one thing that worries them in connexion with the development of atomic energy and allied sources is the effect it will have on their security. If the architects of our present industrial system could reassure the workers that these developments will be used only for their good at all times, if they could ensure that at all times there will be sufficient protective barriers for the workers, I am confident the workers would give these developments their wholehearted support. After all, great advances in science should be directed towards the benefit of the people at al! times. I revert for a moment to the problem of coal. Great changes are taking place in that industry, and we do not know what is ahead of us. I remind honorable senators, for instance, of the saying, " Do not take coal to Newcastle ". At one time, that was looked upon as a joke, but the fact is that coal is being taken to Newcastle to-day. This is because of new developments in the steel industry. To illustrate that, I point out that ore which was suitable for making the cheapest and best steel ten years ago is not a suitable type of ore to-day. As a result of new developments in steel-making, harder ores must be brought from the south coast to Newcastle. That is done not because the coking coal in Newcastle is unsuitable but because of the different composition of the ore now being used. That brings to mind the thought that we should give serious consideration to whether it is wise for us to export coal to Japan. After all, the Japanese are not asking, for instance, for Cessnock coal which we can supply in huge quantities; they are asking for and getting coking coal from the south coast, and we badly need that coal ourselves. I foresee certain dangers to not only our coal industry but also our steel industry if we develop that trade too far. It is possible that we shall have to import coking coal if we develop this export trade; and we should guard against that.

I come now to oil. Recently, in company with other honorable senators, I visited some of the oil-cracking plants, such as the Shell company's refineries at Granville, near Parramatta. Great developments are taking place in coal, oil and hydraulic power. If we have the same development in the nuclear field we could arrive at a position in which there could be danger to the industries of our country. The people there told me that there is no shortage of oil. They can go on producing and when they run out of their present fuel they can commence producing oil from coal. What is more these experts told me that if oil does ever run out, down in Antarctica there are, untouched, hundreds of square miles of the best oil producing shale over which the oil companies have mining leases. So really, there is not likely to be a shortage of fuel for power. All that is likely to happen is a mismanagement of the development of the sources of power in this country.

Because of this, I think the Government would be well advised to set up some committee or organization to study these matters. Senator Spooner said the other night that as a Minister he had three groups of advisers. They included the Joint Coal Board and the Australian Atomic Energy Commission and one other agency. In my opinion those three agencies should be amalgamated into one organization. They should not work in competition but in unison. America is doing that sort of thing and I think that in matters of production, at any rate, we could well take advice from people who have been successful, and who know apparently where they are going.

talk.start.para: - Would coordination not lead to a great monopoly? Would we not lose the benefits of competition if there was too much co-ordination?
I do not think so because lack of co-ordination is leading to monopolies now. Whereas six or seven years ago there were 135 coal mines and the major companies are still combining.
- But we are getting a lot more coal?

Not necessarily a greater total volume. We may be getting more coal from individual mines. Senator Spooner did not say that the national pro duction of coal was greater but that the mines were producing more. There are fewer mines and fewer companies. Huddart Parker Limited the other day took over the controlling interest in the J. and A. Brown and Caledonian collieries. I am not being critical of such a take-over because the company was forced to do it in order to keep the price down to compete on the market. The same sort of thing has happened in Russia. Over there they used to have lots of mines, here, there and everywhere, but now they are amalgamated into socialist groups. The directions of the tunnels were changed and production coordinated, with the result that mining costs have been cut in halves. Perhaps I should not say it, but in a capitalistic sense, that is what is being done here. Mines are being amalgamated and seams are being worked as a whole. Now one company is mining a whole seam in which previously six or seven companies were operating. I am certain that production is now more economical.

speech.para: It was competition between mines in the pre-war years that wrecked the industry by forcing the price down too far. We could once again get down to too low a price in our attempt to keep the industry going. Coal mining has always been a Cinderella industry in a sense. It used to be said by some economists that when conditions were the worst for the mining: industry they were best for the community because the community was getting cheap power. However, that is hardly fair to the coal industry. This Government went to extremes to rectify the situation in the coal-mining industry. We on this side of the chamber have never maintained that, mines should not be given a sufficient price for their coal to enable them to pay, but we think that the coal-mining industry did get very special treatment from this Government. It was given a guaranteed profit operating in New South Wales to-day there of 5s. a ton. That was done in the interests the dangerous level it had reached. To that extent we were in favour of the move because the industry was in a depressed condition. If it had not been depressed it might not have lost its markets both in Australia and overseas.

I realize that, perhaps, the contribution that I have made to this debate has not had much to do with the matters dealt with in the report of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. I have sat on committees in my association with the Joint Coal Board, and 1 know that a lot of talking has to be done and a lot of investigation has to take place. I think we must have experts who can sit down and talk things over. For years I attended committees under Senator Spooner's chairmanship. We discussed amongst other things the possibility of producing oil from coal and briquettes from coal, but all of that discussion came to nothing. Why? All the talking that takes place can have no effect because, after all, economic factors always determine whether a thing can be done or not. The coal owners ask, " Will it pay? Is there any money in it for us? " They say, " If there is not, we are not interested in it". That is plain common sense in the world in which we live to-day.

I do not think this Government should be afraid of the charge that it will become a government of planners. In this new world we are entering we will have to plan; things cannot be left to run as they used to run. If atomic energy is to be a force in this world by 1970 as the report suggests, that calls for a complete revolution in the thinking of all political parties, and particularly in the thinking of the Government parties. In this field we cannot have the kind of thing that Senator Paltridge advocated this morningTrans-Australia Airlines and Ansett-A.N.A., one a socialist enterprise and the other a private enterprise, running side by side and maintained at parity. There will be no such thing as parity. The Government will need to engage in planning because industries are not interested in the type of fuel they burn. All they want is power at the lowest cost. They do not worry whether it comes from gas or electricity, provided it is efficient and cheap. I do not think people arevided it is cheap. It will be the job of governments to provide this cheap power. I hope that while the present Government remains in office it will concern its mind with things like that.

After all, the lives of men and the economic security of people generally are involved in all these changes. I think the Government should institute a vast pro gramme of education to let the people know what is before them. They have a general idea, but if they can be assured that their governments, and the authorities that matter, have their interests at heart, they will be able to make better use of these great advances that are taking place in science than they could possibly do under other circumstances. I think that this is a good report. Most of the scientists associated with the commission are brilliant scientists. Its members also include businessmen and trade union representatives who can exert sufficient influence in the commission to ensure a cautious approach to the scientific side of the subject. Generally speaking, scientists have a habit of pushing ahead with developments irrespective of the damage such developments might cause.

I have heard many scientists make statements at lectures to the effect that their job is to develop scientific inventions and that it is for the politicians and the rest of the community to do what they wish with what is invented. The scientists take the view, in many instances, that it is not their affair whether nuclear energy is used for purposes of war. Some of the greatest scientists are leading the movement for world peace. Professor Oliphant, for in stance, devotes half of his time to developing ideas on nuclear energy and the other half to advocating the erection of protective barriers against the ideas he is developing as a scientist. This indicates the complexity of the world in which we live. Average men and women are just as entitled to be as concerned about these things as are the scientists; they are entitled to consideration in this new world of ours.

I join with my colleagues in saying this is a worthwhile document. We welcome the interest that has been evinced in this matter by the Government, because we wedded to a particular form of power believe that if the developments that taking place in the field of nuclear energy factor in itself has retarded the develop are applied for the benefit of humanity, should1 the world will be the better for it. I like to see the Government give consideration to various aspects of industrial relations, such as the introduction of a shorter working week. Of what use is it to increase productivity without dealing with other problems that increased productivity brings in its wake? I com mend those responsible for the compilation of this report, which is a most interesting document, and I hope that some of them will read in " Hansard" the opinions I have expressed in this speech.

talk.start.para: I should like to add my remarks to those that have been already made on this very important subject. I have read the Australian Atomic Energy Commission's annual report with great interest. I believe that within the next ten or twenty years power will gradually turn to atomic energy. During the past decade, considerable developments in relation to atomic energy have taken place in Europe, the United States of America, Canada, Australia and Russia. In the initial stages after nuclear energy reactors and nuclear powerhouses had been established, it was thought that nuclear power could be produced much more cheaply than power produced from coal and oil. However, it has been proved that at this stage of our history nuclear reactors are not competitive with coal burning stations. Originally, it was anticipated that nuclear reactors would be able to produce power at a cost of about .6d. or .7d. per kilowatt hour. At that time, coal-burning stations in very low-cost areas in Australia were producing power at a cost of from .53 pence to .65 pence per kilowatt houran d they are still producing power at that cost.

speech.para: Doubtless, when the authorities in charge of coal-burning stations were faced immediately with the problem of competing with power produced by nuclear reactors, their technologists and scientists became perturbed and considered the possibility of producing throughout the world cheaper power from coal. It is interesting to note that as a result of scientific and techno logical developments, the latest coal-burning station can produce power at a cost of .4 ment of atomic energy. Whereas the present cost of producing power by nuclear reactors having a production capacity of 250 megawatts is .6 pence or .7 pence per kilowatt hour, it is believed that within the next ten years scientific developments will enable the cost of producing power by nuclear reactors to be reduced approximately to the cost of power generated by coal-burning stations. A lot of theory and thought has been devoted to the number of man hours involved in the establishment of a nuclear power station. I read an article recently that the time involved is 1,500 man-hour-years, that is from the time it is decided to establish an atomic power station and when it comes into production, and that that is equivalent to a period of ten years.

Therefore, the development of power from nuclear energy must be slow. The Australian Atomic Energy Commission has predicted that atomic power stations will be constructed in some of the States and brought to production by the early 1970's and in the remainder by the 1980's, which is twenty years from now. I think that that is a safe prediction. But we also know that throughout the world scientists are studying the use of nuclear reactors and they may be able to discover more economical means of generating power. I have no doubt that they will, and probably much sooner than is anticipated in the report that we are now discussing.

I do not think that coal-burning power stations will be able to reduce their costs of operation below .4 of a penny a kilowatt hour. I think we can safely say that after 100 years of operation and experiment cbal burning stations have now reached optimum efficiency. But this is not so with nuclear reactors, which have only been in existence' for something less than fifteen years. We can expect further developments to take place in nuclear reactors and it is safe to predict that within the next twenty years nuclear reactors will take the place of coal throughout the world for the generation of electricity.

The setting up by this Government of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission and the establishment of a research reactor at Lucas Heights were steps in the right pence per kilowatt hour, or less. That direction. We now have a 10 megawatt plant in operation where scientific experiments may be carried out. Australia has arrangements with the atomic energy com missions of other countries to exchange information. This will lead to cheaper operation of nuclear power plants. At present some of our scientists and technologists are studying atomic energy in other countries and people from overseas are studying at the Lucas Heights establishment Australia ultimately will be setting up nuclear power stations and in its report the Australian Atomic Energy Commission expresses the view that such stations should be established first in northern Queensland and South Australia. I cannot agree with that. I think that the first power station should be built somewhere adjacent to densely populated areas. I think the correct place for a nuclear power station would be somewhere near the Snowy Mountains hydro-electric scheme. Having given the matter much thought, if I had my way I would establish the first reactor on Lake Eucumbene where a plentiful supply of water for cooling would be available. In addition, adequate pump storage facilities would be available.

We can assume that when the reactor is established it will be designed to carry base load. When it is not needed for base load it could be used to pump water from some where downstream' from Lake Eucumbene back into the lake to be used again to meet peak load. In order to operate as cheaply as possible, a reactor would have to be running non-stop. Therefore, I suggest that the first nuclear power station should be established adjacent to a large hydro electric system. It is no use talking about small reactors, because at present they are uneconomical. Any reactor that we establish would have to develop something like 250 megawatts, and a reactor of that size would have to be linked up with the New South Wales and Victorian electricity net works. As I have said, if the reactor were established on Lake Eucumbene when it was not needed for base load it could be used to pump water through a 6-ft. or 12-ft. diameter pipe back into the lake to be re-used through the hydro-electric system as required. Thus, in addition to providing base load output for New South Wales and Victoria, it would enable the re-use of the water from the Snowy scheme.

I suggest that a second reactor should be established not in South Australia or Queensland, but in Western Australia. I do not say that because I come from Western Australia I am not being parochialbu t because a review of the cost of producing electricity in the various States will show that the highest cost is in Western Australia. That is due to the high rail freights from Collie to Perth. I think the cost of producing electricity in Western Australia is in the vicinity of .6 of a penny or .7 of a penny a kilowatt hour. Compare that figure with the cost of .4 of a penny at the new station that is being erected in New South Wales and you will readily see that our industrialists in Western Australia will not be able to compete with undertakings in the east. As the cost of producing electricity is higher in Western Australia than in any other State, the Government should look closely at where the second reactor is established. For the reasons I have given I would like to see it established in Western Australia.

We learn from the report of the commission that uranium mining in Australia has been proceeding satisfactorily. The mines at Radium Hill, Rum Jungle, Mary Kathleen and Alligator River are producing all our uranium oxide. A large plant has been erected at Rum Jungle, and as we know, within a very short period, the sup plies of ore for treatment there will be exhausted. I have noticed with interest that the ore being treated at Rum Jungle contains approximately 2 per cent, of copper and that the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, through the Bureau of Mineral Resources, is conducting a search in the area for additional ore deposits. The mine at Mary Kathleen has come into production. A very large ore body, which will last for many years, is being worked there. I understand that the Rum Jungle mine, through Territory Enterprises Limited, has a contract with either the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority or the Combined Development Agency which expires in 1962. The Mary Kathleen people have a contract which expires in 1965, and so has the Alli gator River Company. It is natural to assume that the price of uranium oxide under future contracts will fall below that of the present contracts, which is approximately 10 dollars per lb. It is possible 414 Australian Atomic [SENATE.] that, because the development of atomic Energy Commission. be made to permit them to continue the power stations throughout the world has slackened, the price will fall still further, and that some of our mines may have to close.

I suggest to the Minister that, if it is at all possible, arrangements should be made with the Combined Development Agency for the provision of funds for the stock piling of uranium oxide. That would be necessary for only a short period, such as five or ten years, until the development of atomic energy got into full swing. I do not think there is any doubt in the minds of those who study this matter that atomic energy produced from the use of uranium oxide will be the power of the future. As we know, the United States of America has submarines which use atomic energy as a source of power. The Russians have built an ice-breaker called " Lenin", which is powered by atomic energy. Atomic power stations are being erected throughout the world. I believe that within a relatively short period the merchant and naval ships of the world will turn to atomic power. That will mean an increased demand for uranium oxide in, say, ten years' time.

The stockpiling of concentrates or of uranium oxide for five or ten years is not impossible. I should hate to see our uranium mines being forced to close because suitable financial arrangements could not production of uranium oxide which, I expect, will be in pretty keen demand in the 1970's and possibly in short supply in the 1980's. I congratulate the Government for carrying on the search for uranium and for having adopted the reward system. As we know, people who go out and locate uranium deposits are paid a reward which, in the case of a large deposit, is 25,000. The scale of rewards has been the same since 1950. In view of the depreciation in the value of the 1, I think that consideration might well be given to increasing the scale of payments, so that 50,000 might be given for the discovery of a large deposit.

There is no doubt in my mind about the necessity to continue the search for uranium, because I think that uranium will be a vital source of power for Australia. We must develop the uses of atomic energy as quickly as possible so that our industries will be able to compete readily with those of other countries. The development of secondary industries depends largely on the availability of power. We must have cheap power. I believe that the cheapest power that it is possible to produce will be developed in the future from the use of atomic energy. I ask for leave to continue my remarks at a later date.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
